intro: Abies nobilis var. glauca, commonly known as the white fir, is a variant of the noble fir native to the western United States. It is characterized by its silvery-blue foliage, which gives it a distinctive appearance. The leaves are needle-like, typically measuring between 1 and 2 inches in length, and are arranged spirally along the branches. This evergreen tree can grow to heights of up to 100 feet, forming a conical shape with a broad, spreading crown. Its cones are small and reddish-brown, maturing within a single season.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abies nobilis var. glauca is primarily native to the western United States, particularly in areas of California, Oregon, and Washington. This variant of the white fir is commonly found in high elevation forests and mountainous regions. It thrives in cool, moist climates with well-drained soils. The plant is often associated with mixed coniferous forests and is adapted to the harsh conditions of its native habitat. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones where it can receive adequate moisture and sunlight.

It was often introduced for its ornamental value due to its distinctive blue-green foliage and conical shape. The distribution of this variety has been limited to areas where it can thrive without significant competition from native species. It is commonly found in mountainous regions of western North America, particularly in areas with well-drained soils.
